post-text: And by the way, all you teachers out there not that many of you are going to die, so don't worry about it. Don't worry about it.

text: <So let's talk about caring about the American people. The American people who have had to sacrifice far too much because of the incompetence of this administration.>
post-text: It is asking too much of the people Susan, we talked about the American people It is asking too much of the people that they would not be equipped with the information they need to help themselves to protect their parents and their children.
label: Appeal to False Authority

text: <I don't want the federal government paying teachers' salaries directly. But if the money will go to the states and the states can then determine whether it shall go for school construction or for teachers' salaries, in my opinion you protect the local authority over the school board and the school committee.>
post-text: And therefore I think that was a sound proposal and that is why I supported it and I regret that it did not pass.
label: Appeal to False Authority

text: <None We might have no other choice. We'll have to see if that happens.>
post-text: The thing about Iraq, of course, was at the end of the war we had pretty well decimated their military.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <If you look back over the last eight years, the most significant accomplishments of this administration in which Al Gore was centrally involved were the result, most of them, of bipartisan agreements.>
post-text: After all, the Welfare Reform Act, which Al Gore promised to lead the effort on to get people off of welfare to set time limits, to get people to enjoy the dignity of work. That was a bipartisan act that was adopted. The Anti-Crime Act that has helped to lower crime more than 287% in our country was also bipartisan. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 which was critical to getting our economy to the point and our government to the point of unprecedented surplus we enjoy today also was bipartisan, and Al Gore was involved. I would say that's exactly the kind of bipartisan leadership that he and I can bring to Washington to get things done.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: <That's a basic principle. It was ignored in that case and it was a very very serious mistake in judgment.>
post-text: None
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <Why do they have to say we're going to be attacking Mosul within the next four to six weeks, which is what they're saying? How stupid is our country?>
post-text: I can't think of any.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <May I respond briefly? What the vice president has just said is just a complete distortion.>
post-text: The American people saw John Kerry on Thursday night.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <I wasn't just getting more power and more power.>
post-text: So I rolled the dice, I put my career on the line because I really believe the future of America is on the line. We can give you all these numbers, they don't mean a thing.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <We've done a lot to give the people more powers to make their own decisions over their own lives. But I do think we are right when we try to, for example, give mothers and newborns 48 hours before they can be kicked out of the hospital, ending these drive-by deliveries.>
post-text: I think we were right to pass the Kassebaum-Kennedy bill, which says you can't lose your health insurance just because you change jobs or because someone in your family's been sick.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <I believe that this president, regrettably, rushed us into a war, made decisions about foreign policy, pushed alliances away.>
post-text: And, as a result, America is now bearing this extraordinary burden where we are not as safe as we ought to be. The measurement is not: Are we safer?
label: Appeal to Emotion

pre-text: I mean, we thought we'd whip more of them going in.
text: <But because Tommy Franks did such a great job in planning the operations, we moved rapidly, and a lot of the Baathists and Saddam loyalists laid down their arms and disappeared.>
post-text: I thought they would stay and fight, but they didn't.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <The neighborhood, the kind of environment people are growing up in, and that leads me to the programs I'm talking about in terms of education.>
post-text: I think that part of it is the crime infested neighborhoods, and that's why I'm a strong believer in trying to control crimes in the neighborhood, why I was so pleased to be endorsed by the policemen on the beat, the Boston Police Department the other day. I think they understand my commitment to helping them in the neighborhoods.
label: Appeal to False Authority

text: <I mentioned Halliburton a few minute ago in connection with the $87 billion, and you raised it in this question.>
post-text: This is relevant, because he was pushing for lifting sanctions when he was CEO of Halliburton. Here's why we didn't think Halliburton should have a no-bid contract.
label: Ad Hominem

text: <To me, that's the best way to secure America.>
post-text: I believe it was a failure of presidential leadership not to reauthorize the assault weapons ban. I am a hunter.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <When you have your staff taking the Fifth Amendment, taking the Fifth so they're not prosecuted, when you have the man that set up the illegal server taking the Fifth, I think it's disgraceful.>
post-text: And believe me, this country thinks it'sreally thinks it's disgraceful, also. As far as my tax returns, you don't learn that much from tax returns.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <Al Gore and I have felt for a long time, first as parents and then only second as public officials, that we cannot let America's parents stand alone in this competition that they feel they're in with Hollywood to raise their own kids and give their kids the faith and values they want to give them. I've been a consistent crusader on that behalf.>
post-text: John McCain and I actually requested the Federal Trade Commission report that came out three or four weeks ago which proved conclusively that the entertainment industry was marketing adult-rated products to our children.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <Look, that's where World War I started in the Balkans.>
post-text: My uncle was a victim of poisonous gas there. Millions of Americans saw the results of that conflict.
label: Appeal to Emotion

pre-text: I want to come back and tell you why, but if you will forgive me, I would like to say something right now at the beginning of this debate following on the moment of silence for Mel Carnahan and Randy Carnahan and Chris Sifford.
text: <Tipper and I were good friends with Mel and Randy, and I know that all of us here want to extend our sympathy and condolences to Jean and the family and to the Sifford family.>
post-text: And I would just like to say that this debate in a way is a living tribute to Mel Carnahan because he loved the vigorous discussion of ideas in our democracy.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <What's the net result of this?>
post-text: This means that the average family income went up fifteen per cent in the Eisenhower years as against two percent in the Truman years. Now, this is not standing still.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: <Franklin Roosevelt said in 1932 that the only thing we have to fear is fear itself.>
post-text: The only thing, Jim, they have to offer is fear. Fear of the environment, fear of the climate, fear of Medicare, fear of Newt, fear of Republicans, fear of Bob, and probably fear of cutting tax rates.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <In my judgment that statement has been distorted uh-by Mr. Nixon and others in their debates around the country and in their discussions. Mr. Lodge, on "Meet the Press" a month ago, said if there was ever a case when we did not have law an our side it was in the U-2 incident.>
post-text: The U-2 flights were proper from the point of view of protecting our security.
label: Appeal to False Authority

text: <Well, first of all, for the last four years we have worked had to put more and more pressure on the Castro government to bring about more openness and move toward democracy. In 1992, before I became President, the Congress passed the Cuba Democracy Act and I enforced it vigorously.>
post-text: We made the embargo tougher but we increased contacts people to people with the Cubans, including direct telephone service, which was largely supported by the Cuban-American community.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <There's -- you don't have to take my word for this.>
post-text: There is now a federal judge's opinion about the current management of this program ordering the State of Texas to do -- you should read that judge's language about this. I believe there are 1.4 million children in Texas who do not have health insurance.
label: Appeal to False Authority

text: <You've been all over the country repeating something that, I will admit, the press has also been repeating -- that I believed that nuclear missiles could be fired and then called back.>
post-text: I never, ever conceived of such a thing. I never said any such thing. In a discussion of our strategic arms negotiations, I said that submarines carrying missiles and airplanes carrying missiles were more conventional-type weapons, not as destabilizing as the land-based missiles, and that they were also weapons that -- or carriers -- that if they were sent out and there was a change, you could call them back before they had launched their missiles.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <My plan would dedicate $24 billion a year in each of the next 4 years for investments in new transportation, communications, environmental clean-ups and new technologies for the 21st century.>
post-text: And we would target it especially in areas that have been either depressed or which have lost a lot of defense related jobs. There are 25757,575757 people in California, for example, who have lost their defense related jobs. They ought to be engaged in making high speed rail.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <Donald.>
post-text: I've met dishwashers, painters, architects, glass installers, marble installers, drapery installers, like my dad was, who you refused to pay when they finished the work that you asked them to do. We If you would have told me I was going to make that 15 or 251 years ago, I would have been very surprised. But that's the kind of thinking that our country needs.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <We've spent over $633 billion so far, soon to be $1 trillion.>
post-text: We have lost over 4,161616 lives. We have seen 321,212121 wounded, and most importantly, from a strategic national security perspective, al Qaeda is resurgent, stronger now than at any time since 243431. We took our eye off the ball.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: <Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized. For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives, and the result, a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together.>
post-text: We've got to do something about it.
label: Appeal to Emotion

pre-text: If you were going to pass something in the Congress, you had to show where you are going to pay for it and how.
text: <President Bush has taken -- he's the only president in history to do this.>
post-text: He's also the only president in 72 years to lose jobs -- 1. 6 million jobs lost. He's the only president to have incomes of families go down for the last three years; the only president to see exports go down; the only president to see the lowest level of business investment in our country as it is today. Now, I'm going to reverse that.
label: Appeal to Emotion

pre-text: President Trump and I have great confidence in the American people and their ability to take that information and put it into practice.
text: <In the height of the epidemic, when we were losing a heartbreaking number of 2,53737 Americans a day, we surged resources to New Jersey, and New York, and New Orleans and Detroit.>
post-text: We told the American people what needed to be done and the American people made the sacrifices.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <We'll make sure they do not end up with weapons of mass destruction. It's the great nexus.>
post-text: The great threat to our country is that these haters end up with weapons of mass destruction.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <My objection here is not the cost in dollars. My objection here is the potential cost in controls and eventual freedom for the American people by giving the federal government power over education, and that is the greatest power a government can have.>
post-text: When uh-the Vice President quotes me in January, sixty, I do not believe the federal government should pay directly teachers' salaries, but that was not the issue before the Senate in February.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <Well, thank you for asking your question. And I've heard this question from a lot of Muslim-Americans across our country, because, unfortunately, there's been a lot of very divisive, dark things said about Muslims.>
post-text: And even someone like Captain Khan, the young man who sacrificed himself defending our country in the United States Army, has been subject to attack by Donald. I want to say just a couple of things.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <Ninety-nine United States senators voted for it. And the president's been very busy running around the country using what I just described to you as a reason to say I'm wishy-washy, that I'm a flip-flopper.>
post-text: Now that's not a flip-flop.
label: Ad Hominem

text: <We've seen him embarrass women on TV and on Twitter.>
post-text: We saw him after the first debate spend nearly a week denigrating a former Miss Universe in the harshest, most personal terms. So, yes, this is who Donald Trump is. But it's not only women, and it's not only this video that raises questions about his fitness to be our president, because he has also targeted immigrants, African-Americans, Latinos, people with disabilities, POWs, Muslims, and so many others. So this is who Donald Trump is.
label: Ad Hominem

pre-text: This is a very important issue we're talking about.
text: <Senator Obama voted against Justice Breyer and Justice Roberts on the grounds that they didn't meet his ideological standards. That's not the way we should judge these nominees.>
post-text: Elections have consequences.
label: Appeal to False Authority

text: <But I've supported Medicare ever since. In fact, I used to go home, my mother would tell me, Bob, all I've got is my Social Security and my Medicare, don't cut it. I wouldn't violate anything my mother said. In fact, we had a conversation about our mothers one day, a very poignant conversation in the White House. I'm concerned about healthcare.>
post-text: I've had the best healthcare from government hospitals, Army hospitals and I know its importance, but we've got to fix it.
label: Appeal to False Authority

text: <None Civility, responsibility, racial reconciliation, healing the wounds of our country has to be one of the greatest, most singularly important goals for this country here on the edge of the 21st Century.>
post-text: How in the name of American democracy can we say to eastern Europe that democratic capitalism will work there if we can't make it work in East L.A. or East Harlem or East Palo Alto, California?
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <But when you're in a race, the only way to stay ahead is to move ahead.>
post-text: And I subscribe completely to the spirit that Senator Kennedy has expressed tonight, the spirit that the United States should move ahead. Where, then, do we disagree?
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <It is just wrong. It is unAmerican, and to think that in the 21st Century this kind of nonsense is still going on.>
post-text: We have to stop it.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <Not at all, Mr. Trewhitt, and I want you to know that also I will not make age an issue of this campaign. I am not going to exploit, for political purposes, my opponent's youth and inexperience.>
post-text: [Laughter and applause] If I still have time, I might add, Mr. Trewhitt, I might add that it was Seneca or it was Cicero, I don't know which, that said, "If it was not for the elders correcting the mistakes of the young, there would be no state.''
label: Ad Hominem

text: <Oh, I'm it's my question. But whether I agree or disagree with some individual, or what he may say, or how he may say it, I don't think there's any way that we can suggest that because people believe in God and go to church, that they should not want reflected in those people and those causes they support, their own belief in morality, and in the high traditions and principles which we've abandoned so much in this country.>
post-text: Going around this country, I think that I have found a great hunger in America for a spiritual revival.
label: Appeal to False Authority

text: <Because someone didn't meet exactly our standards of human rights, even though they were an ally of ours, instead of trying patiently to persuade them to change their ways, we have, in a number of instances, aided a revolutionary overthrow which results in complete totalitarianism, instead, for those people. I think that this is a kind of a hypocritical policy when, at the same time, we're maintaining a detente with the one nation in the world where there are no human rights at all-the Soviet Union.>
post-text: Now, there was a second phase in the Iranian affair in which we had something to do with that.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <While they were on the ground fighting, they lobbied the Congress to cut their combat pay. This is the height of hypocrisy.>
post-text: Well, Gwen, it's hard to know where to start; there are so many inaccuracies there.
label: Ad Hominem

pre-text: And the kind of plan that Donald has put forth would be trickle-down economics all over again. In fact, it would be the most extreme version, the biggest tax cuts for the top percent of the people in this country than we've ever had.
text: <I call it trumped-up trickle-down, because that's exactly what it would be.>
post-text: That is not how we grow the economy. We just have a different view about what's best for growing the economy, how we make investments that will actually produce jobs and rising incomes. I think we come at it from somewhat different perspectives.
label: Ad Hominem

text: <My opponent thought there was weapons there.>
post-text: That's why he called him a grave threat. I wasn't happy when we found out there wasn't weapons, and we've got an intelligence group together to figure out why.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <They don't want to go into a drug bust and be facing an AK-47.>
post-text: I was hunting in Iowa last year with a sheriff from one of the counties there, and he pointed to a house in back of us, and said, "See the house over? We just did a drug bust a week earlier, and the guy we arrested had an AK-47 lying on the bed right beside him. Because of the president's decision today, law enforcement officers will walk into a place that will be more dangerous.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <Of course that's a charge that's always made against any governor who runs for the presidency. I think it was one of the things that Mr. Bush said about Mr. Reagan back in 19833.>
post-text: Remember that, George?
label: Appeal to False Authority

text: <And I've -- and we've always said that that's not appropriate. But to somehow say that group of young women who said "Military wives for McCain" are somehow saying anything derogatory about you, but anything -- and those veterans that wear those hats that say "World War II, Vietnam, Korea, Iraq," I'm not going to stand for people saying that the people that come to my rallies are anything but the most dedicated, patriotic men and women that are in this nation and they're great citizens.>
post-text: And I'm not going to stand for somebody saying that because someone yelled something at a rally -- there's a lot of things that have been yelled at your rallies, Senator Obama, that I'm not happy about either.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <We have lived through what Jean Kirpatrick called the bloodiest century in mankind's history.>
post-text: We have defeated in this system of ours fascism, Nazism, communism, socialism is defunct or debunked around the world, the evil of apartheid has ended. There is only one last question remaining for the next century, indeed the next millennium.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <We just see the world in different ways. And you folks out there are going to have to choose who you think is right.>
post-text: Well, I'd say the first homeless bill in the Senate was the Dole-Byrd Byrd-Dole bill, I can't remember who was in control then.
label: Appeal to False Authority

text: <If you look at it and think about it, we now have in our most disadvantaged communities, 717% of our fourth graders can't read at the basic level of understanding. We've graduated 15 million kids from high school in the last few years who can't read at a significant level. They are permanently sentenced to a lifetime of failure.>
post-text: What we want to do is to change that.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <But we also want our education to be free of federal control. When the federal government gets the power to pay teachers, inevitably in my opinion, it will acquire the power to set standards and to tell the teachers what to teach. I think this would be bad for the country; I think it would be bad for the teaching profession.>
post-text: There is another point that should be made.
label: Slippery Slope

text: <I think that the means that I advocate will reach that goal better than the means that he advocates. I could give better examples, but for-for whatever it is, whether it's in the field of housing, or health, or medical care, or schools, or the eh- development of electric power, we have programs which we believe will move America, move her forward and build on the wonderful record that we have made over these past seven and a half years.>
post-text: Now, when we look at these programs, might I suggest that in evaluating them we often have a tendency to say that the test of a program is how much you're spending.
label: Appeal to Emotion

pre-text: And they were graphically demonstrated again today.
text: <America needs a new direction.>
post-text: We cannot be satisfied with what we've been doing for the last eight years.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: <And I want all of you to know that you'll always be in our hearts and in our prayers.>
post-text: But when you say what the American people have done over these last eight months hasn't worked, that's a great disservice to the sacrifices the American people have made. I'm referring to your president.
label: Appeal to False Authority

text: <She doesn't have the look. She doesn't have the stamina.>
post-text: I said she doesn't have the stamina.
label: Ad Hominem

text: <Here's why we didn't think Halliburton should have a no-bid contract.>
post-text: While he was CEO of Halliburton, they paid millions of dollars in fines for providing false information on their company, just like Enron and Ken Lay. They did business with Libya and Iran, two sworn enemies of the United States.
label: Ad Hominem
